I’ve said it before & I’ll say it again: to invest in our HBCUs is to invest in GA & the U.S.

As we’re coming out of this pandemic, what better time than now to invest in American infrastructure & jobs?

In honor of #AAPIHM, I want to recognize the contributions Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders make to GA’s culture & community every day. I know the past year has been difficult, but as we move forward I’ll continue to uplift, listen to & learn from our AAPI friends & neighbors.

RT @SenSherrodBrown As global temperatures rise, workers from Ohio to California are increasingly exposed to dangerous heat.

On #NationalHeatAwarenessDay, I'm proud to sponsor legislation with @SenAlexPadilla to protect workers from heat stress on the job.

Every worker deserves a safe workplace.

RT @CAinsider "For most of my Republican Colleagues that didn’t have the backbone to stand up for what’s right… is a dereliction of duty." 

@SenAlexPadilla reacts to GOP Senators blocking a #Jan6Commission. I'm teaming up with @SenSherrodBrown to protect these workers from heat stress on the job.

#NationalHeatAwarenessDay

A minority of my Republican colleagues were able to block a January 6th commission that a majority of the Senate voted to move forward with—one meant to investigate a deadly attack on our democracy. If this isn't proof that the filibuster is undemocratic, I don't know what is.

If my Republican colleagues will filibuster a bipartisan, independent commission—one that they themselves negotiated the terms of—to investigate an attack on our democracy, what else will they filibuster?
 
We shouldn't wait to find out.

Today, we honor Captain Cindy Gats for her service to our nation. #JewishAmericanHeritageMonth

Captain Gats is an observant Orthodox Jew and openly celebrated Shabbat and other Jewish holidays throughout her service, including attending religious services during her deployment to Saudi Arabia. She also managed and organized religious services for her fellow Marines.
In 1990, Captain Gats served in Operation Desert Shield and worked within 22 miles of the front lines when Operation Desert Storm began in 1991.
After Gats studied at @penn_state, she was commissioned as a lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps. After her promotion to captain, Gats served at Marine Corps Air Station El Toro in California.

Today in the #WomensVetsTaskForce series highlighting the achievements of Jewish American #womenvets, we recognize Captain Cindy Gats, a Desert Storm veteran and former communications specialist and paratroop squadron leader in the @USMC. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2fvimjXMAIHpyE.jpg

If we end the filibuster, we can strengthen voting rights, pass universal background checks, raise the minimum wage, and more.
 
We can protect our democracy, and we can make progress on the urgent issues Americans elected us to address.
 
Let's get it done. End the filibuster.

Eliminating the filibuster won't mean the end of minority views.
 
That's what our system of checks and balances is for.
 
But a filibuster that has frozen our ability to pass overwhelmingly popular reforms isn’t a healthy check and balance –
 
It’s a roadblock to progress.

Simply put, America is at a tipping point. 

It’s not tenable for the will of the majority of the voters to be continually thwarted by an archaic rule.

We need to end the filibuster so we can protect and strengthen our democracy.

So we can make progress — and make it lasting.

The filibuster has a shameful legacy:
 
In the 1960s, segregationists used it to block civil rights legislation, including anti-lynching laws.
 
And today, Republicans are using it block progress on everything from preventing gun violence to protecting voting rights, and more.

The filibuster is an arcane Senate rule requiring 60 votes instead of a simple majority to end debate on a piece of legislation and bring it to a vote.

And while the filibuster has a long history, it's not written in the Constitution.

Here's why we should end it:

Senate Republicans blocked the creation of a bipartisan commission to investigate the January 6 insurrection, despite the fact that a majority of Senators — and a majority of Americans — support it.
 
How? Two words: The filibuster.
 
THREAD:

Republicans aren't being honest about the Jan. 6 commission.
 
It's bipartisan, with equal members from both parties. Subpoenas require a bipartisan vote. We agreed to Republicans' 2021 deadline.
 
Their sham complaints distract from the real motive:
 
To hide the truth.

It's a painful day for American democracy that Republicans blocked the creation of a commission to investigate the Jan. 6th insurrection. I applaud the six Republicans who voted for the commission, but I am saddened that so many are too intimidated by Trump to do the right thing.
